response:

<<<code>>>: activity.findViewById(R.id.imageView)
<<<explanation>>>: To make the image visible by time counter, you can use the Android Animation framework to animate the visibility of the image using the `Animation` class. Here's an example code snippet that shows how to animate the visibility of an image using the `Animation` class:
```java
// Get the image view
ImageView imageView = (ImageView) activity.findViewById(R.id.imageView);

// Create a new animation using the Animation class
Animation animation = new AlphaAnimation(1.0f, 0.0f);
animation.setDuration(500); // Animation duration in milliseconds
animation.setRepeatCount(1); // Repeat the animation once

// Set the image view as the target of the animation
imageView.startAnimation(animation);

// Create a new animation using the Animation class
animation = new AlphaAnimation(0.0f, 1.0f);
animation.setDuration(500); // Animation duration in milliseconds
animation.setRepeatCount(1); // Repeat the animation once

// Set the image view as the target of the animation
imageView.startAnimation(animation);
```
In this example, we create two `AlphaAnimation` objects, one to animate the image becoming invisible and another to animate the image becoming visible. The `setDuration()` method is used to set the duration of the animation in milliseconds, and the `setRepeatCount()` method is used to specify that the animation should be repeated once. Finally, we call the `startAnimation()` method on the image view to start the animation.

You can modify this code snippet to suit your specific needs, such as changing the image views, animations, and durations.
